Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation2: The ambulance driver is on standby at the station, ready for any new dispatch to come in.
Story:
I was sitting in the ambulance, engine idling, waiting for the next call. My radio crackled with static, a constant reminder that at any moment, I might have to speed off to save a life. I glanced out the window and saw my stepbrother, Jamie, on the sidewalk across the street. He was fiddling with his phone, not paying attention as he stepped off the curb. My heart lurched—he didn’t see the car coming down the road, and I knew he never looked both ways.

As his step-sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he was safe, especially since our parents always said, “Take care of each other.” But as an ambulance driver, I was expected to stay put, ready to respond instantly to any emergency. If I left my post, even for a second, I could miss a call that meant life or death for someone else. My hands gripped the steering wheel, torn between the urge to shout his name and the duty to stay ready. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, and I felt frozen, caught between two impossible choices.
